memo_header.subject: Vueltas Del Rio Project â€“ Review Summary

introduction.summary: This memo summarizes a desktop level review of the Vueltas Del Rio gold project in Honduras. The review was high-level, without detailed due diligence or a site visit. P&E's review included preliminary mineral resource model construction, pit optimization, production scheduling, and financial modelling.

project_history.title: 1. HISTORY
project_history.production_summary: The mining and processing operation produced 118,265 oz of gold at an approximate grade of 1.8 g/t.

mineral_resource_estimate.title: 2. MINERAL RESOURCE ESTIMATE
mineral_resource_estimate.methodology: P&E undertook a mineral resource update based on a drilling database acquired from past project involvement in 2003. The database contains 451 drill holes and 230 pits and trenches.

open_pit_optimization.title: 3. OPEN PIT OPTIMIZATION
open_pit_optimization.purpose: To assess the potential size of the mineable portion of the mineralized body, a pit optimization exercise was completed based on the newly developed P&E mineral resource model and input parameters.

production_schedule.title: 4. PRODUCTION SCHEDULE
production_schedule.basis: Conceptual schedule targeting 1 Mtpa mineralized material delivery to the heap leach crusher.
production_schedule.peak_mining_rate: 4 Mtpa of combined mineralized material and waste.

economic_cashflow_modelling.title: 5. ECONOMIC CASHFLOW MODELLING
economic_cashflow_modelling.methodology: An Excel-based cashflow model was developed to determine gold production, annual revenues, costs, and discounted cashflows. All costs are in US dollars.

conclusion.title: 6. CONCLUSION
conclusion.summary: The review summary indicates the Vueltas del Rio deposit is a potentially very robust project with a very high IRR and very short payback. This is attributed to the high average gold grade (approx. 1.4 g/t) and low operating cut-offs (0.15 to 0.35 g/t range).
conclusion.recommendation: The Vueltas del Rio project is a very worthy acquisition target, and the next stage of due diligence should be undertaken without delay.
